title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.

Menta, K., Bani-Yaghoub, M., & Youan, B.C. (2023). Understanding Periodic Dynamics of p53-Mdm2 Interactions with the Stable Limit Cycles. Submitted to Cell Cycle.

title: Projects
text:
arXiv Preprint | Code
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

title: Projects
section: The History of the War of the Ring
text:
The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth’s history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

title: Welcome to my website!
text:
LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  
  
    
     Email
  




Welcome to my website!
Kathryn Menta is a first year PhD student in Epidemiology and Biostatistics at Case Western Reserve University. A former crime scene investigator and forensic scientist, Kathryn now plans to use her crime solving skills in the field of biostatistics, hopefully in the field of clinical trials and chronic illness management.
On this website, you will find a selection of my projects and published works. Please note that this website is a work in progress and that the projects page will be updated at a later date. Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects.

title: Blog
text:
When writing, presenting, or talking about scientific (or really any type of) work, it is important to remember to KISS: Keep It Simple, Stupid. When I was training in crime scene investigation and preparing to testify in court, it was always said to talk and explain things to the jury at a 6th grade level. Yes, even complex scientific findings! By this time, I had become quite good at this, as the job I had before going into law enforcement was explaining state unemployment benefits and the ins and outs of the unemployment system in the state of Florida’s claimant call center. Being able to clearly explain complicated concepts is a skill that needs to be learned and used by all.
Writing papers is hard. Writing papers explaining scientific concepts is even harder. From Jeffrey Leek’s “How to be a Modern Scientist”, the statement “Learn how to write papers in a very clear and simple style” struck a chord with me. Many people are suspicious of simple writing and can make others doubt the importance of the work you are hoping to publish. If no one reads the paper because it is written in extremely technical terms that only a niche group of people understand, then there is no point in writing the paper.
Write possible publications in a manner where you think most people can read and understand. You want to clearly communicate your results stemming from hours of research and/or experimentation. As Leek says, “Simple, clear language leads to much higher use/reading/citation/impact of your work”. The more people who understand your writing, the greater impact your writing can be to your community and the world at large.
